content.webTitle: Rose Byrne: 'I couldn't do standup, my comedy comes from character, not jokes'

fields.headline: Rose Byrne: 'I couldn't do standup, my comedy doesn't come from jokes'
fields.bodyText: Rose Byrne is a notorious “breaker” – one of those actors who finds it impossible to keep a straight face opposite a comedic co-star. While she assures me she’s improving, working with her “unpredictable” co-star Melissa McCarthy on their new movie Spy made it almost impossible. “She’ll go on these runs of her bits, so it’s pretty hard not to start laughing. Even the crew guys start laughing.” She adds quickly: “Jude [Law] broke a lot so that made me feel less self-conscious.” For Byrne, it’s an occupational hazard. The Sydney-born actor has made a slew of comedies since her 2010 role as trashtastic popstar Jackie Q, the girlfriend of Russell Brand’s character in Get Him to the Greek. Next came the wildly successful Bridesmaids, in which she played the insufferable Helen opposite Kristen Wiig and Maya Rudolph, followed by the bromance Bad Neighbours, in which she played Seth Rogen’s wife and casually walked away with most of the kudos. Her fast track to funny girl is no accident. When I interviewed Byrne in 2010, before Greek, she spoke of a desire to do more comedy after a run of solemn-faced roles in the Asperger’s drama Adam, the horror flick 28 Weeks Later and the sci-fi thriller Sunshine. She said then: “Most of my stuff has been serious … but I definitely have a light-hearted side.” She has channelled it. Spy reunites her with the Bridesmaids director, Paul Feig, and co-star McCarthy. Billed as an action comedy, the film sees McCarthy’s mild-mannered CIA analyst Susan Cooper forced out into the field – in increasingly depressing cat-lady disguises – to stop an underworld nuclear arms deal. Byrne plays the dastardly Raina Boyanov, a mob boss’s daughter who is possibly the linchpin in the deal and the foil for McCarthy’s unfortunate character. The two banter and bounce off each other, locked in a tussle of wits and, occasionally, limbs. Despite her growing assuredness, she finds comedy challenging, particularly when working with “effortless” performers such as Wiig, Rudolph and McCarthy. “It’s like doing a drama but on top of that you have to get a laugh,” she says, “It’s scientific, it’s technical and it’s also like lightning in a bottle.” Her approach is different to that of her co-stars: “I could never do standup – my comedy comes from character stuff, not necessarily from jokes.” What makes her laugh in real life? “Fox news. That’s pretty funny.” At 35, Byrne is one of Australia’s most successful actors. Audiences have watched her transform from the fresh-faced (albeit peroxided) 20-year-old in Two Hands, opposite Heath Ledger, through a blink-and-you-missed-it performance in Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones, a screen kiss with Brad Pitt in the forgettable Troy and a role as the extravagant Duchesse de Polignac in Sofia Coppola’s lightweight Marie Antoinette. Then came Damages, her breakout television role in which she played a law school graduate locked in a dysfunctional relationship with her mentor/tormentor, played by Glenn Close. The show premiered in 2007, the same year as Mad Men, and was one of the new breed of TV dramas, headed up by strong female leads. It ran for five seasons. Looking back, Byrne says she realises it was a seminal time: “I was lucky to be part of that really great writing that was returning to TV.” The role got her noticed – and two Golden Globe nominations. By 2013 she was one of LA’s most in-demand actors, reportedly having her pick of TV scripts during pilot season. Instead she focused on getting her funny on. While more likely to be cracking a smile on screen, she’s getting more serious off screen. Until recently, Byrne could never have been accused of being outspoken but in 2014 she appeared in a public service announcement on US television about sexual assaults on college campuses. Inspired by the campaign, she followed it up by taking part in a women’s day at the UN in New York. “I thought it was a really hard subject to discuss that nobody really wants to.” She’s also entered the debate about sexism in the film industry. Byrne points to a push by the American Civil Liberties Union for a criminal investigation into gender discrimination. “It’s not being put down to good old-fashioned misogyny, it’s actually [asking] why is this quietly tolerated? Why has this been a silent agreement for the last however many years. “This is discrimination. And that’s illegal. It’s very interesting, long overdue and quite frankly exciting to see it being taken as seriously as it should be.” Byrne and a group of close friends have taken matters into their own hands. Documentary film-maker Gracie Otto, actor and writer Krew Boylan, director Shannon Murphy, publicist Jessica Carrera and Byrne decided to band together to form the Dollhouse Collective, a production company with an emphasis on creating “complicated great lead roles for women”. The fivesome intend to mix and match duties, with Byrne keen to produce and direct. “As an actor, you have little control over your career, whereas you can exercise a little bit more of that when you are steering the ship.” She feels a responsibility to Australia. “You want to give back, to tell Australian stories and nurture the place where you are from.” She won’t say if the newly announced Screen Australia funding cuts will affect the company’s first project Seriously Red, written by Boyland and executive produced by Byrne. But she was disappointed to hear about them. “It just seems to be more bad news with this government with the arts. It’s not a priority for them to cultivate our storytelling or our culture through artistic pursuits.” Still, she continues to enjoy the lighter side of her work. She’s pleased when I point out red carpet shots in which she looks increasingly chipper. “I’m used to people telling me I was miserable so it’s nice to have a change of tune.” Time to press her for a reason. Is it her increasingly comedic roles that are making her smile? Her confidence as a red carpet regular? Or perhaps the happiness she’s reportedly found with her partner, actor Bobby Cannavale? She laughs hard. “Maybe I’ve had a few glasses of wine before I got on there, that’s probably it.” • Spy is out now in Australia and released on 5 June in the US and UK
